title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to glyrepr
text: outlines propose change glyrepr. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to glyrepr
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to glyrepr
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to glyrepr
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("fubin1999/glyrepr", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to glyrepr
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to glyrepr
text: Please note glyrepr project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

what: Representation for Glycan Structures in R

title: Representation for Glycan Structures in R
text: can install development version glyrepr GitHub :

title: Representation for Glycan Structures in R
code: library(glyrepr)  glycan <- n_glycan_core() print(glycan, verbose = TRUE) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─GlcNAc (b1-4) #>   └─Man (b1-4) #>     ├─Man (a1-3) #>     └─Man (a1-6)

what: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
text: glycan graph subclass igraph graph additional constraints. function checks constraints append S3 class glycan_graph graph object. Generally, recommended create glycan graph using function manually. Use glyparse package generate glycan graph structure string. Two types glycan graphs supported: dual-node (DN) node-edge (NE). NE glycan graph directed modeling glycan structure, nodes monosaccharides edges linkages. DN glycan graph another way model glycan structure, monosaccharides linkages nodes. Monosaccharides linkages alternate DN glycan graph. details, see "details" section. as_dn_glycan_graph() as_glycan_graph() type = "dn". as_ne_glycan_graph() as_glycan_graph() type = "ne".

title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
text: graph igraph graph object. type character string specifying glycan graph type. can "auto", "ne", "dn". "auto" (default), function tries infer type, raises error . "ne" "dn", function assumes graph specified type.

title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
text: glycan graph object.

title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
text: glycan graph merely igraph graph additional S3 class glycan_graph. Based type glycan, ne_glycan_graph dn_glycan_graph also appended graph. Therefore, sloop::s3_class() glycan graph either c("ne_glycan_graph", "glycan_graph", "igraph") c("dn_glycan_graph", "glycan_graph", "igraph").

title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
text: intuitive way model glycan structure. Nodes represent monosaccharides edges represent linkages. Constraints: graph must directed outward tree (reducing end root). graph must graph attribute anomer, form "a1". graph must vertex attribute mono monosaccharide names. graph must vertex attribute sub substituents. graph must edge attribute linkage linkages. Monosaccharide name must known, either generic (Hex, HexNAc, etc.) concrete (Glc, Gal, etc.), mixture . NA allowed. Substituent must valid, form "xY", x position Y substituent name, e.g. "2Ac", "3S", etc. Linkages must valid, form "/bX-Y", X Y integers, e.g. "b1-4", "a2-3", etc. NA allowed.

title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
text: another way model glycan structure. mode, monosaccharides linkages nodes, alternate graph represent structure. Python library glycowork glypy use model. intuitive, allows flexible motif matching. Constraints: graph must directed outward tree (reducing end root). graph must graph attribute anomer, form "a1". graph must vertex attributes type, mono, sub, linkage. type either "mono" "linkage". NA allowed type. mono linkage monosaccharide name linkage, respectively. nodes type = "mono", linkage always NA. nodes type = "linkage", mono sub always NA. Monosaccharide name must known, either generic concrete, mixture . nodes type = "mono", NA allowed mono. Substituent must valid. nodes type = "mono", NA allowed sub. Linkages must valid. nodes type = "linkage", NA allowed linkage. mono nodes linkage nodes must alternate graph. another word, edge must connect mono node linkage node. outermost nodes (nodes -degree 0) must mono nodes, linkage nodes.

title: Convert igraph Graph to Glycan Graph — as_glycan_graph
code: library(igraph) #>  #> Attaching package: ‘igraph’ #> The following objects are masked from ‘package:stats’: #>  #>     decompose, spectrum #> The following object is masked from ‘package:base’: #>  #>     union  # A simple NE glycan graph: GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc graph <- make_graph(~ 1-+2)  # 1 and 2 are monosaccharides V(graph)$mono <- c("GlcNAc", "GlcNAc") V(graph)$sub <- "" E(graph)$linkage <- "b1-4" graph$anomer <- "a1" as_glycan_graph(graph) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (a1-) #> └─GlcNAc (b1-4)  # A simple DN glycan graph: GlcNAc(b1-4)GlcNAc graph <- make_graph(~ 1-+2, 2-+3)  # 1 and 3 are monosaccharides, 2 is linkage V(graph)$type <- c("mono", "linkage", "mono") V(graph)$mono <- c("GlcNAc", NA, "GlcNAc") V(graph)$sub <- c("", NA, "") V(graph)$linkage <- c(NA, "b1-4", NA) graph$anomer <- "a1" as_glycan_graph(graph, type = "dn") #> Glycan Graph (DN) #> GlcNAc: 2 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (a1-) #> └─b1-4 #>   └─GlcNAc

what: Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
title: Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
text: function converts monosaccharides glycan graph different type. types : concrete, generic, simple. conversion can done "concrete" "generic" "simple", "generic" "simple". Conversion orders allowed.

title: Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
text: glycan glycan graph. character string specifying target monosaccharide type. can "concrete", "generic", "simple". strict TRUE, function raise error monosaccharides already target type. Default TRUE.

title: Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
text: glycan graph monosaccharides converted target type.

title: Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
text: three types monosaccharides: concrete: e.g. "Gal", "GlcNAc", "Glc", "Fuc", etc. generic: e.g. "Hex", "HexNAc", "HexA", "HexN", etc. simple: e.g. "H", "N", "S", "F". full list monosaccharides, see glyrepr::monosaccharides.

title: Convert the Type of Monosaacharides in a Glycan Graph — convert_glycan_mono_type
code: concrete_glycan <- n_glycan_core(mono_type = "concrete") convert_glycan_mono_type(concrete_glycan, to = "generic") #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> Hex: 3, HexNAc: 2 #> ------------------ #> HexNAc (?1-) #> └─HexNAc (b1-4) #>   └─Hex (b1-4) #>     ├─Hex (a1-3) #>     └─Hex (a1-6) convert_glycan_mono_type(concrete_glycan, to = "simple") #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> H: 3, N: 2 #> ------------------ #> N (?1-) #> └─N (b1-4) #>   └─H (b1-4) #>     ├─H (a1-3) #>     └─H (a1-6) generic_glycan <- n_glycan_core(mono_type = "generic") convert_glycan_mono_type(generic_glycan, to = "simple") #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> H: 3, N: 2 #> ------------------ #> N (?1-) #> └─N (b1-4) #>   └─H (b1-4) #>     ├─H (a1-3) #>     └─H (a1-6)

what: Convert between NE and DN glycan graphs — convert_graph_mode
title: Convert between NE and DN glycan graphs — convert_graph_mode
text: function converts Node-Edge (NE) glycan graph Dual-Node (DN) glycan graph, vice versa. NE glycan graph, nodes represent monosaccharides edges represent linkages. DN glycan graph, monosaccharides linkages nodes, alternate. See as_glycan_graph() details.

title: Convert between NE and DN glycan graphs — convert_graph_mode
Convert between NE and DN glycan graphs — convert_graph_mode
text: glycan glycan graph. target graph mode, either "ne" "dn". strict TRUE, error thrown glycan already target mode. FALSE, glycan returned . Default TRUE.

title: Convert between NE and DN glycan graphs — convert_graph_mode
text: converted glycan graph object.

title: Convert between NE and DN glycan graphs — convert_graph_mode
code: (glycan <- n_glycan_core(mode = "ne")) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─GlcNAc (b1-4) #>   └─Man (b1-4) #>     ├─Man (a1-3) #>     └─Man (a1-6)  # Convert to DN mode convert_graph_mode(glycan, to = "dn") #> Glycan Graph (DN) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─b1-4 #>   └─GlcNAc #>     └─b1-4 #>       └─Man #>         ├─a1-3 #>         │ └─Man #>         └─a1-6 #>           └─Man  # Converting to NE mode will raise an error try(convert_graph_mode(glycan, to = "ne")) #> Error in convert_graph_mode(glycan, to = "ne") :  #>   The glycan is already in "NE" mode.  # Set `strict` to `FALSE` to return the glycan unchanged convert_graph_mode(glycan, to = "ne", strict = FALSE) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─GlcNAc (b1-4) #>   └─Man (b1-4) #>     ├─Man (a1-3) #>     └─Man (a1-6)

what: Determine if a Glycan Graph has Linkages — has_linkages
title: Determine if a Glycan Graph has Linkages — has_linkages
text: Unknown linkages glycan graph represented "??-?". function checks linkages glycan graph unknown. Note even one linkage partial known (e.g. "?-?"), function return TRUE.

title: Determine if a Glycan Graph has Linkages — has_linkages
Determine if a Glycan Graph has Linkages — has_linkages
text: glycan glycan graph.

title: Determine if a Glycan Graph has Linkages — has_linkages
text: logical value indicating glycan graph linkages.

title: Determine if a Glycan Graph has Linkages — has_linkages
code: glycan <- o_glycan_core_1(mode = "ne", linkage = TRUE) has_linkages(glycan) #> [1] TRUE print(glycan) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> Gal: 1, GalNAc: 1 #> ------------------ #> GalNAc (a1-) #> └─Gal (b1-3)  glycan <- remove_linkages(glycan) has_linkages(glycan) #> [1] FALSE print(glycan) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> Gal: 1, GalNAc: 1 #> ------------------ #> GalNAc (a1-) #> └─Gal

Check if an Object is a Glycan Graph — is_glycan
text: x object checked.

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
text: Create example glycan graphs testing demonstration. Includes N-glycan core O-glycan core 1 core 2.

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
code: n_glycan_core(mode = "ne", linkage = TRUE, mono_type = "concrete")  o_glycan_core_1(mode = "ne", linkage = TRUE, mono_type = "concrete")  o_glycan_core_2(mode = "ne", linkage = TRUE, mono_type = "concrete")

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
text: mode character string, either "ne" "dn". See as_glycan_graph() details. linkage logical indicating whether include linkages (e.g. "b1-4"). Default TRUE. mono_type character string specifying type monosaccharides. Can "simple" (H, N, F, S), "generic" (Hex, HexNAc, dHex, NeuAc, etc.), "concrete" (Man, Gal, HexNAc, Fuc, etc.). Default "concrete".

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
text: glycan graph object.

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
text: N-Glycans branched oligosaccharides bound, commonly, via GlcNAc Asn residue protein backbone. common motif N-glycans chitobiose core, composed three mannose two GlcNAc moieties, commonly attached protein backbone via GlcNAc. mannose residue branched connected via α1,3- α1,6-glycosidic linkages two mannose building blocks.
code: Man   a1-6 \   b1-4      b1-4         Man -- GlcNAc -- GlcNAc   a1-3 /     Man

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
text: O-Glycans highly abundant extracellular proteins. Generally, O-glycans extended following four major core structures: core 1, core 2, core 3, core 4. first two far common core structures O-glycosylation found throughout body. core 1:   core 2:
code: GalNAc    / b1-3 Gal GlcNAc       \ b1-6        GalNAc       / b1-3    Gal

title: Example Glycan Graphs — n_glycan_core
code: print(n_glycan_core(mode = "ne"), verbose = TRUE) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─GlcNAc (b1-4) #>   └─Man (b1-4) #>     ├─Man (a1-3) #>     └─Man (a1-6) print(o_glycan_core_1(mode = "dn"), verbose = TRUE) #> Glycan Graph (DN) #> Gal: 1, GalNAc: 1 #> ------------------ #> GalNAc (a1-) #> └─b1-3 #>   └─Gal

title: Generate Possible Linkages — possible_linkages
text: Given obscure linkage format ("?", e.g. "a2-?"), function generates possible linkages based format. See valid_linkages() details. ranges possible anomers, first positions, second positions can specified using anomer_range, pos1_range, pos2_range.

title: Generate Possible Linkages — possible_linkages
code: possible_linkages(   linkage,   ...,   anomer_range = c("a", "b"),   pos1_range = 1:2,   pos2_range = 1:9,   include_unknown = FALSE )

title: Generate Possible Linkages — possible_linkages
text: linkage linkage string. ... used. anomer_range character vector possible anomers. Default c("", "b"). pos1_range numeric vector possible first positions. Default 1:2. pos2_range numeric vector possible second positions. Default 1:9. include_unknown logical value. TRUE, "?" included. Default FALSE.

title: Generate Possible Linkages — possible_linkages
text: character vector possible linkages.

title: Generate Possible Linkages — possible_linkages
code: possible_linkages("a2-?") #> [1] "a2-1" "a2-2" "a2-3" "a2-4" "a2-5" "a2-6" "a2-7" "a2-8" "a2-9" possible_linkages("??-2") #> [1] "a1-2" "b1-2" "a2-2" "b2-2" possible_linkages("a1-3") #> [1] "a1-3" possible_linkages("a?-?", pos1_range = 2, pos2_range = c(2, 3)) #> [1] "a2-2" "a2-3" possible_linkages("?1-6", include_unknown = TRUE) #> [1] "a1-6" "b1-6" "?1-6"

what: Print method for Glycan Graphs — print.ne_glycan_graph
title: Print method for Glycan Graphs — print.ne_glycan_graph
text: function prints information glycan graph, including composition structure.

title: Print method for Glycan Graphs — print.ne_glycan_graph
code: # S3 method for class 'ne_glycan_graph' print(x, ..., verbose = TRUE)  # S3 method for class 'dn_glycan_graph' print(x, ..., verbose = TRUE)

title: Print method for Glycan Graphs — print.ne_glycan_graph
text: x glycan graph. ... Ignored. verbose logical value. TRUE, structure glycan graph printed. Default TRUE.

title: Print method for Glycan Graphs — print.ne_glycan_graph
text: NE glycan graphs, linkages unknown ("??-?"), linkage information omitted.

what: Remove All Linkages from a Glycan Graph — remove_linkages
title: Remove All Linkages from a Glycan Graph — remove_linkages
text: unkonwn linkage glycan graph represented "??-?". function replaces linkages glycan graph "??-?", has_linkages() return FALSE.

title: Remove All Linkages from a Glycan Graph — remove_linkages
Remove All Linkages from a Glycan Graph — remove_linkages
text: glycan glycan graph.

title: Remove All Linkages from a Glycan Graph — remove_linkages
text: glycan graph linkages removed.

title: Remove All Linkages from a Glycan Graph — remove_linkages
code: glycan <- n_glycan_core() print(glycan) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─GlcNAc (b1-4) #>   └─Man (b1-4) #>     ├─Man (a1-3) #>     └─Man (a1-6)  glycan <- remove_linkages(glycan) print(glycan) #> Glycan Graph (NE) #> GlcNAc: 2, Man: 3 #> ------------------ #> GlcNAc (?1-) #> └─GlcNAc #>   └─Man #>     ├─Man #>     └─Man

what: Check if Linkages are Valid — valid_linkages
title: Check if Linkages are Valid — valid_linkages
text: Valid linkages form "a1-2", "b1-4", "?-1", etc. Specifically, pattern xy-z: x: anomer, either "", "b", "?". y: first position, either "1", "2" "?". z: second position, either 1-9 digit "?". Can also multiple positions separated "|", e.g. "1|2|3". "?" used "|".

title: Check if Linkages are Valid — valid_linkages
Check if Linkages are Valid — valid_linkages
text: linkages character vector linkages.

title: Check if Linkages are Valid — valid_linkages
text: logical vector.

title: Check if Linkages are Valid — valid_linkages
code: # Valid linkages valid_linkages(c("a1-2", "?1-4", "a?-1", "b?-?", "??-?", "a1|2-3")) #> [1]  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE  TRUE FALSE  # Invalid linkages valid_linkages(c("a1-2|?", "1-4", "a|b1-2", "c1-2", "a9-1")) #> [1] FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE
